Plants.Benefits: Trap for leaf miners. Attracts Ground beetle which preys on slugs, snail, cutworm and cabbage-root maggot.
Repels aphids, weevils, carrot flies, moles, fruit tree borers. Controls rust flies and some nematodes; protects tomatoes against red spiders. Protects roses from black spot, mildew and aphids.
Can be lethally poisonous from ingesting any part.

Licorice flavored herb, good host for predatory wasps which prey on aphids and it is also said to repel aphids. Deters pests from broccoli by camouflaging their odor. Depending upon your plans Anise is supposed to increase the essential oil production in basil.

Plants.Companions: Dill, Coriander, Tomato, Parsley, Basil, Marigold, Comfrey, Strawberry
Plants.Benefits: Marigolds will deter beetles. Plant broad leaved annual vegetables or strawberries between the asparagus rows and they will thrive.

Artichokes' height also can provide sturdy supports for climbing plants and they can provide shade for smaller, more vulnerable plants. Tubers do not make good companions to artichokes as the root systems of both plants inhibits growth against both crops.

Plants.Companions: Pepper, Tomato, Marigold, Asparagus, Oregano, Petunias
Plants.Benefits: Repels aphids, flies, mosquitos and mites; helps control insect pests such as tomato hornworms, asparagus beetles, and disease. Basil will kill your rosemary. Depending upon your plans Anise is supposed to increase the essential oil production in basil.
Great for attracting birds, butterflies, and bees. Pretty perennial that tends to get powdery mildew.

Plants.Companions: Bush Beans, Cabbage, Onion, Sage, Lettuce, Kohlrabi, Brassica
Plants.Benefits: Good for adding minerals to the soil. The leaves are composed of 25% magnesium making them a valuable addition to the compost pile if you don't care to eat them.
They should also not be grown near apricot trees because a fungus that the pepper is prone to can cause a lot of harm to the apricot tree.
Black walnut trees inhibit the growth of apples, potato, eggplant, tomato, capsicum, blackberry, petunia.

Repels tomato worms. Adds potassium, calcium and other minerals to soil. Attracts honeybees. Borage may benefit any plant it is growing next to via increasing resistance to pests and disease. It also makes a nice mulch for most plants. Borage and strawberries help each other and strawberry farmers always set a few plants in their beds to enhance the fruits flavor and yield. Plant near tomatoes to improve growth and disease resistance. After you have planned this annual once it will self seed. Borage flowers are edible.

Plants.Incompatible: Mustards, Nightshades, Tomato, Peppers, Strawberry, Beans
Plants.Benefits: Brassicas are a family of species which include broccoli, cabbage, brussel sprouts, kohlrabi, and cauliflower. Need rich soil with plenty of lime to flourish.
Add nitrogen to soil--which is needed by corn. Bean vines grow up corn stalks, thus anchoring corn more firmly and the vines discourage racoons.
Accumulates calcium and can be grown as an excellent cover crop. Attracts hoverflies in droves. Do not plant buckwheat as a companion crop with legumes, as its early competitiveness for nutrients.

Plants.Companions: Beets, Cabbage, Carrot, Celery, Corn, Cucumbers, Eggplant, Lettuce, Pea, Radish, Strawberry, Savory, Tansy, Marigold, Potato, Sunflower
Plants.Benefits: Encourages growth of companion plant. Adds nitrogen to the soil. Green beans protect eggplant from the Colorado potato beetle.

Plants.Companions: Bush Beans, Beets, Celery, Onion, All Strong Herbs, Marigold, Nasturtium
Plants.Incompatible: Strawberry, Tomato, Pole Beans, Mustard, Peppers
Plants.Benefits: Rosemary repels cabbage flies, geraniums trap cabbage worms, same general companion profile as all brassica.
Good for loosening compacted soil with its deep roots so it's also compatible next to shallow rooted crops. The flowers attract a number of beneficial insects especially the tiny parasitic wasps.

Plants.Companions: Bush Beans, Pole Beans, Lettuce, Onion, Peas, Radish, Tomato, Sage, English Peas, Rosemary, Flax
Plants.Benefits: Tomatoes may stunt carrots' growth.
Repels moles and plant lice. Note: All parts of castor beans are poisonous.

Fresh catnip steeped in water and sprinkled on plants will drive away flea beetles. Deters flea beetles, aphids, Japanese beetles, squash bugs, ants and weevils, and mice. Helps distract cats from rest of the garden.

Plants.Companions: Bush Beans, Cabbage, Onion, Spinach, Tomato, Leek, Brassica, Nasturtium
Plants.Benefits: Improves growth of companion plants. Repels white cabbage butterflies.

Improves growth and flavor--but plant only one plant every 150 feet or so. Growing chamomile of any type is considered a tonic for anything you grow in the garden. Host to hoverflies and wasps. Growing near herbs will increase their oil production.
Can be problematic with some herbs that need high nutrition. Maintains ground humidity and attracting beneficial insects.
Improves growth and flavor.

Plants.Companions: Rose, Carrot, Tomato, Apples, Broccoli, Cabbage, Beet, Mustard
Plants.Benefits: Improves growth and flavor.

Kills root nematodes. White flowering chrysanthemums repel Japanese beetles. Repel pest insects from nearby crops and ornamental plants (aphids, bed bugs, leafhoppers, spider mites, harlequin bugs, ticks, pickleworms and imported cabbage worms)
Good trap crop for slugs.
Repels aphids, spider mites, and potato beetle. Attracts bees.

Plants.Companions: Amaranth, Bush Beans, Pole Beans, Cucumber, Melons, Peas, Squash, Irish Potato, English Peas, Pumpkin, Morning Glory, Parsley, Sunflower
Plants.Benefits: Used in the "three sisters" technique (maize, squash, and climbing beans) When the maize is 15 cm (6 inches) tall, beans and squash are planted around the maize, alternating between beans and squash.

Plants.Companions: Comfrey, Borage, Geranium, Sage, Nasturtium, Thyme
Plants.Benefits: Repels moths. Place costmary behind lower growing herbs but definitely in front of giants such as elecampane.

Plants.Companions: Bush Beans, Pole Beans, Corn, Lettuce, Onion, Peas, Radish, Marigold, Nasturtium, Savory, Sunflower, English Peas, Dill
Plants.Benefits: Improves growth. Vines growing with corn help anchor corn and discourage racoons.
Deters Japanese beetles. Note: All parts of the Datura plant are poisonous! It can produce skin irritations in some people.

Improves growth. Draws in many beneficial insects as the umbrella flower heads go to seed. Blossoms attract honeybees, butterflies/caterpillars, Hoverflies, Wasps, Tomato Horn Worms (bad for tomatoes). Repels aphids, spider mites, squash bugs, cabbage looper.

Plants.Companions: Bush Beans, Pole Beans, Spinach, Marigold, Tarragon
Plants.Benefits: Avoid planting them in close proximity to peppers, tomatoes and potatoes as they attact common pests.
Most plants dislike fennel--so plant it away from the vegetable garden. Its foliage and flowers may attract beneficials. Repels fleas, so grow it around dog kennel.
Flax contains tannin and linseed oils which may offend the Colorado potato bug.
Draws Japanese beetles like a magnet which then dine on the foliage. The foliage is pure poison to them!
Should not follow: eggplant, tomatoes, potatoes, or peppers and other raspberry varieties in the crop rotation.
Repels aphids, weevils, carrot flies, moles, fruit tree borers; Controls rust flies and some nematodes; protects tomatoes against red spiders. Protects roses from black spot, mildew and aphids.

Plants.Companions: Cabbage, Corn, Grape, Rose, Tomato, Peppers, Eggplant
Plants.Benefits: Repels cabbage worms, Japanese beetles. Acts as a trap crop.

Use horehound directly as a companion plant. It attracts predatory wasps and flies. It grows where many others fail to thrive and can survive harsh winters. Said to stimulate tomatoes and peppers to produce fruit, improving quality as well as yield. The small white flowers attract many beneficial insects.
Encourages growth. May repel Colorado potato beetles and blister beetles.

Plants.Companions: Onion, Cucumber, Eggplant, Escarole, Tomato, Okra, Swiss Chard, Squash, Basil, Oregano, Parsley, Rosemary, Geranium, Petunia
Plants.Benefits: Have root exudates that prevent root rot and other Fusarium diseases.

Improves growth, deters cabbage moth. Hyssop may be the number one preference among bees and some beekeepers rub the hive with it to encourage the bees to keep to their home. It is not as invasive as other members of the mint family making it safer for interplanting.

Plants.Companions: Barrenwort, Hosta, Bugleweed, Carex, Bleeding Heart
Plants.Benefits: Repels potato bugs. A good plant to use for naturalizing, massing or as a ground cover.
Attract Japanese beetles and kills them Larkspur is poisonous to humans!
Improves growth for celery, onions, and apple trees. Repels carrot flies.
Wards off squash bugs. Plant freely throughout the garden.

Plants.Companions: Bush Beans, Pole Beans, Carrot, Cucumber, Onion, Radish, Strawberry
Plants.Incompatible: Irish Potato, Strong Herbs, Celery, Cabbage, Cress, Parsley
Plants.Benefits: Mints (including hyssop, sage, and various "balms") repel slugs, a bane of lettuce and cabbages.

Plants.Companions: Cucumber, Asparagus, Bean, Beet, Brassica, Onion, Leek, Peas, Potato, Lettuce, Squash, Zucchini, Corn, Tomato
Plants.Benefits: Like borage and geraniums, lovage is considered a "magic bullet" of companion planting. It improves the flavor and vigor of most plants.

Encourages growth, deters Mexican bean beetles and other pests. Discourages harmful nematodes, if they are grown for several seasons in the ground in areas that have nematode infestations. Should not be planted near any legume crop due to antibacterial thiophenes exuded by the roots.
Improves the flavor of vegetables and herbs.

Plants.Companions: Corn, Nasturtium, Radish, Pumpkins, Marigold, Oregano

Plants.Benefits: Improves flavor and growth. Earthworms are quite attracted to mint plantings. Be careful where you plant it as mint is an incredibly invasive perennial.

Plants.Companions: Cabbage, Brassica, Radish, Brussel Sprouts, Turnip, Collard, Kohlrabi
Plants.Benefits: Plant mustard as a trap crop. It attracts numerous insect pests. Remove and destroy it before your main crops can be harmed.

Plants.Companions: Cucumber, Radish, Squash, Broccoli, Cabbage, other vegetables, fruit trees
Plants.Benefits: Repels aphids, cucumber beetles, whiteflies and squash bugs. Acts as trap crop for aphids. Repels borers near fruit trees. leaves, flowers and seeds are all edible and wonderful in salads.

Plants.Companions: Beets, Cabbage, Carrot, Celery, Cucumber, Lettuce, Pepper, Squash, Strawberry, Tomato, Savory, Rose, Chamomile, Cauliflower, Broccoli
Plants.Benefits: Repels aphids, weevils, carrot flies, moles, fruit tree borers; Controls rust flies and some nematodes; protects tomatoes against red spiders. Protects roses from black spot, mildew and aphids. Planting chamomile and summer savory with onions improves their flavor.

Plants.Companions: Broccoli, Cabbage, Cucumber, Cauliflower, Brassica, Grape
Plants.Benefits: Repels cabbage butterfly. Can be used with most crops. Repels cabbage butterflies and cucumber beetles.

Plants.Companions: Tomato, Asparagus, Carrot, Rose, Onion, Chive
Plants.Benefits: Deters asparagus beetles.Improves growth. Deters carrot flies and rose beetles. Parsley increases the fragrance of roses when planted around their base. Useful for protecting tomato plants as the wasps that kill tomato hornworms also eat nectar from parsley.
Encourages growth of corn and squash.

Plants.Companions: Bush Beans, Pole Beans, Carrot, Corn, Cucumber, Radish, Turnip, Celery, Chicory, Spinach, Parsley
Plants.Benefits: Adds nitrogen to soil for use by hungry corn plants. Grows well with carrots, turnip, radish, cumcumber, beans and potatoes.
Discourages ants, plant lice, cabbage maggots. Note: Highly toxic to cats.
Repels white cabbage moths, aphids and flea beetles. It is the menthol content in mints that acts as an insect repellant. Attracts Bees.
They repel the asparagus beetle, leafhoppers, certain aphids, tomato worms, Mexican bean beetles and general garden pests. Acts as a trap crop. Plant everywhere.

Plants.Companions: Carrot, Corn, Cucumber, Eggplant, Lettuce, Pea, Radish, Savory, Tansy
Bush Beans, Cabbage, Carrot, Celery, Flax, Horseradish, Marigold, Peas, Petunia, Onion
Plants.Incompatible: Cucumber, Kohlrabi, Parsnip, Pumpkin, Rutabaga, Squash, Sunflower, Turnip, Fennel, Tomato

Plants.Benefits: Repels aphids, leafhoppers, spider mites, harlequin bugs, ticks, pickleworms and imported cabbage worms.

Plants.Companions: Bush Beans, Pole Beans, Carrot, Cucumber, Lettuce, Melons, Peas, Squash, Nasturtium, Chervil, Melons, Parsnip, Spinach, Broccoli
Plants.Incompatible: Hyssop, Cabbage, Cauliflower, Brussel Sprouts, Turnip
Plants.Benefits: Deters cucumber beetles. Radishes may protect squash from squash borers. Chervil and nasturtium are known to improved growth and flavor of radishes.

Plants.Companions: Cabbage, Broccoli, Beans, Garlic, Onion, Rose
Plants.Benefits: Rhubarb helps deter red spider mites and also protects against black flies.
Repels carrot flies, bean beetles, cabbage moths.
Repels Japanese beetles. Keep it far away from Sweet Basil; plant near roses and raspberries.
Repels carrot flies, cabbage moths, ticks. Plant with rosemary, cabbage and carrots; keep away from cucumbers. Deters cabbage moth, carrot fly.
Improves growth. Attracts Bees. Deters bean beetles.
Repels aphids, weevils, carrot flies, moles, fruit tree borers. Controls rust flies and some nematodes. Protects tomatoes against red spiders. Protects roses from black spot, mildew and aphids.
Enhances growth of corn.

Wonderful lemony scent. Doesn't like fertilizer. Repels Cabbage loopers, Flea Bettles, Cabbageworms, Moths. Plant here and there in garden; companion to cabbage; improves Growth and flavor, deters cabbage moth.
Add nitrogen to the soil
Deters ants, aphids.

Plants.Companions: Cabbage, Celery, Eggplant, Cauliflower, Strawberry, Faba Beans
Plants.Benefits: There are no known bad companions for spinach.

Plants.Companions: Borage, Corn, Onion, Radish, Nasturtium, Marigold, Melons, Oregano
Plants.Benefits: Borage will help deter worms and impove growth and flavor. Radishes will prevent insects on the squash plant.

Plants.Companions: Bush Beans, Lettuce, Onion, Spinach, Borage, Thyme
Corn, Artichoke, Broad Beans, Bush Beans, Cucumber, Squash
Plants.Benefits: Attracts Humming birds and bees. The bright blossoms draw ladybugs and ants, both of which feed on aphids. Create shade for less heat-tolerant plants.
Direct seed or set out starts of sweet alyssum near plants that have been attacked by aphids in the past. Alyssum flowers attract hoverflies whose larva devour aphids.

Plants.Companions: Basil, Okra, Cucumber, Eggplant, Escarole, Tomato, Chard , Squash, Oregano, Parsley, Rosemary
Plants.Benefits: Improves growth. Do not plant near apricot trees because a fungus that the pepper is prone to can cause a lot of harm to the apricot tree.

Plants.Companions: Cucumber, Squash, Rose, Grape, Raspberry, Blackberry
Plants.Benefits: Deters flying insects, striped cucumber beetles, ants, flies, squash bugs and Japanese beetles. Note: attracts cabbageworms. Toxic to many animals.
Plant throughout the garden, not many pests like this one. Recommended to enhance growth and flavor of vegetables.

Plants.Companions: Cabbage, Broccoli, Kale, Egg-Plant, Potato, Tomato
Plants.Benefits: Controls flea beetles, cabbage maggots, imported cabbageworms and white cabbage butterflies.

Plants.Companions: Carrot, Celery, Onion, Mint, Rose, Nasturtium, Marigold, Asparagus, Parsley, Cucumber
Plants.Benefits: Protects roses from black spot. May stunt carrot growth.
Deters black flea beetles, malaria mosquitos, cabbage worm butterflies. Keeps animals away when planted as a border.
Insect repelling qualities. Plant along borders, near paths, near aromatic herbs; enhances essential oil production of herbs. Improves soil quality. Leaves make great compost.
Acts as a trap crop for leaf miners. Host for beet leafhopper insect. Should be allowed to grow in moderate amounts in the garden, especially in corn.
Adds phosphorus. Good anywhere in garden. Good in compost heaps and good for earthworms.

Plants.Companions: Radish, Catnip, Broccoli, Tansy, Dill, Marigold
Plants.Benefits: Gourds can develop bacterial wilt. Cucumber Beetles, Squash bugs, Squash vine borer, Cut worms, and Aphids are all possible pests.
Attracts beneficial insects.
Rye influences 100% germination of Pansy.
Attracts a variety of predatory insects. The root also contains Myristricin, which is toxic to fuit flies, house flies, red spider mite, pea aphids.
Used as a natural ground cover in agriculture.

Plants.Companions: Grape, Apple Trees, Brassica , Corn, Cucumber, Squash, Melons
Plants.Benefits: Fertilizes the soil for neighboring plants. Attracts many beneficials. Useful planted around apple trees to attract predators of the woolly aphid.

Plants.Companions: Fruit trees, Tomato, Pepper, Potato, Cabbage, Broccoli, Kohlrabi, Carrot
Plants.Benefits: Repels slugs, aphids, carrot fly, cabbage worms and can be eaten like chives.

Plants.Companions: Tomato, Pepper, Cucumber, Broccoli, Brussel sprouts, Cauliflower
Plants.Benefits: Repels cabbage worms, cucumber worms and beetles, tomato horn worms. Makes a good ground cover.

Plants.Companions: Beet, Onion, Oregano, Mint, Sage, Thyme
Plants.Benefits: Beets and kohlrabi grow perfectly together
Attract hoverflies and Ladybugs. Fast growing vines provides cover.
Attract beneficial insects. Repels moths and fleas. Discourages mice, moths and ticks.

Plants.Companions: Cucumber, Basil, Melon, Peas, Lettuce, Eggplant
Plants.Benefits: Provides shade for lettuce.
Attract wasps, hoverflies, and humming birds. Plant freely throughout the garden. Zinnia is notorious as a target for mold and fungal growths.
Attract honeybees, wasps, and ladybugs. Angelica is really a short-lived perennial and dies after its flowering year.

Plants.Companions: Brussel Sprouts, Bean, Celery, Dill, Hyssop, Mint, Nasturtium, Sage
Plants.Benefits: Do not allow to go to seed. Burdock will spread fast and wide.
Blackberries grows very quickly and can take over if not pruned frequently.

Plants.Companions: Basil, Beans, Onion, Corn, Mint, Radish, Nasturtium
Plants.Benefits: Zucchini will thrive when planted with nasturtium, corn or marigold. Nasturtiums will distract the pests from attacking your zucchini and other squash plants.

Plants.Companions: Allium, Chive, Garlic, Geranium, Lavender, Leek, Marigold, Onion, Parsley, Rhubarb, Rue, Shallot, Tansy, Tomato
Plants.Benefits: Tomatoes and Allium protects roses from black spot while parsley deters rose beetles. Lavender makes a great cover for mature roses' bare legs.
Salad burnet has the flavor described as light cucumber and is considered interchangeable with mint in some recipes.

Plants.Companions: Cucumber, Squash, Brassica, Spinach, Lettuce, Rosemary, Dill, Strawberry
Plants.Benefits: Lupins make good companion plants for crops that need significant amounts of nitrogen in their soil. Attracts honeybees. They can fix nitrogen from the atmosphere into ammonia via a rhizobium-root nodule symbiosis, fertilizing the soil for other plants. The legume seeds of lupins are edible and have a full range of essential amino acids.

Dissuade aphids, moths, and other bothersome insects in the garden. Can inhibit growth of nearby plants. Mugwort likes to grow alone, consider planing in a pot or isolated container so not to interfer with the growth of other plants. Weak mugwort tea spray works as a natural insecticide. Leaves and stalks can be used as kindling.

Plants.Companions: Borage, Clover, Tomato, Greens, Peppers, Nasturtiums
Plants.Benefits: Offers soil nouirishment. Presence can decreases insect damage to other plants. Can be eaten raw in salads. Fast growing.
